verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews living in the land of Egypt — those in Migdol, Tahpanhes, Memphis, and in the country of Pathros:
verses.comment: The message addresses the Jewish exiles who settled throughout Egypt, a result of their flight from Babylonian conquest.

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, says: You have seen all the disaster I brought on Jerusalem and on all the towns of Judah. They lie in ruins today because of the evil they did.
verses.comment: God frames the judgment as righteous consequence for rebellion, reaffirming His justice and the reality of covenant blessings and curses (cf. Deut. 28).

verses.text: Because of their wickedness — they made Me angry by burning incense and serving other gods that neither they, you, nor your fathers ever knew.
verses.comment: Idolatry is at the root of their judgment. The language echoes the first commandment (Ex. 20:2-5) and recalls how worship shapes the covenant community.

verses.text: I sent all My servants the prophets to you again and again, saying, ‘Do not do this detestable thing that I hate.’
verses.comment: God's patience shines as He sends repeated warnings through the prophets, a reminder of His persistent love and desire for their repentance.

verses.text: But they did not listen or turn from their evil; they kept burning incense to other gods.
verses.comment: Here is the persistent hard-heartedness of the people. The refusal to repent demonstrates the necessity of both human cooperation with grace and deeper conversion.

verses.text: Therefore, My furious anger was poured out; it blazed in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem, which are now desolate and ruined, as they are today.
verses.comment: Divine wrath is not capricious but a just judgment. The ruins of Jerusalem provide a somber warning to heed God's guidance.

verses.text: Now the Lord God Almighty, the God of Israel, says: Why are you bringing this great disaster on yourselves by cutting off from Judah every man and woman, child and infant, leaving none to remain?
verses.comment: God’s question highlights the self-destructive nature of sin, which leads to the loss of life across generations.

verses.text: Why do you provoke Me to anger with the works of your hands, burning incense to other gods in Egypt, where you have come to live? You will be cut off and become a curse and a reproach among all the nations of the earth.
verses.comment: The setting in Egypt is significant: Israel is repeating errors from the Exodus (cf. Ex. 32), suggesting that deliverance must be matched with continued faithfulness.

verses.text: Have you forgotten the evils of your ancestors, the kings of Judah and their wives, your own evils and those of your wives, which were committed in the land of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.comment: A collective memory is required for repentance; forgetting the consequences of sin perpetuates cycles of unfaithfulness.

verses.text: To this day they have not humbled themselves or shown reverence. They have not followed My law or My statutes I set before you and your ancestors.
verses.comment: Humility before God and fidelity to His instruction are the conditions of restoration. The law is seen as a path, not a burden.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I am determined to bring disaster on you and to destroy all Judah.
verses.comment: The sovereign will of God is displayed in the decree of judgment, reminding the faithful that divine justice is perfect.

verses.text: I will take the remnant of Judah who have set their faces to go to the land of Egypt to live there, and they shall all be consumed. They will fall by the sword and famine. They will become an object of horror, a curse, a disgrace.
verses.comment: Even the remnant is not immune to justice outside the land of promise, highlighting a theology of sacred place and belonging.

verses.text: I will punish those who dwell in the land of Egypt, as I punished Jerusalem, with sword, famine, and plague.
verses.comment: The universal reach of God's judgment is asserted, but within it is hope: the call to turn and be saved.

verses.text: Of the remnant of Judah who have come to settle in the land of Egypt, none will escape or survive to return to the land of Judah, to which they long to return and live. Only a few fugitives will escape.
verses.comment: Despite the overwhelming judgment, a mysterious 'few' will remain, reflecting God’s pattern of preserving a remnant (cf. Isa. 10:20-22).

verses.text: Then all the men who knew that their wives had burned incense to other gods, along with all the women present—a large crowd—and all the people living in Pathros in Egypt, answered Jeremiah:
verses.comment: The response comes from both men and women, demonstrating widespread rebellion. The inclusion of women indicates communal participation in idolatry.

verses.text: As for the word you have spoken to us in the name of the Lord, we will not listen to you!
verses.comment: Open rejection of prophetic instruction shows the depth of estrangement, underscoring the need for a living, united authority to interpret God’s word faithfully.

verses.text: But we will certainly do whatever we have vowed: We will burn incense to the Queen of Heaven and pour out drink offerings to her, just as we and our fathers, our kings and our officials, did in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. For then we had plenty of food and were well and saw no disaster.
verses.comment: The reference to the 'Queen of Heaven' signals syncretism and an appeal to false security in traditions separate from God's covenant. The attraction of visible prosperity can mislead hearts away from true worship.

verses.text: But ever since we stopped burning incense to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out drink offerings to her, we have lacked everything and have been consumed by sword and famine.
verses.comment: A misunderstanding of causality: they attribute their suffering to neglecting false worship rather than to covenant breach. Spiritual blindness comes from refusing correction.

verses.text: And when we burned incense to the Queen of Heaven and poured out drink offerings to her, did our husbands not know that we were making cakes shaped in her image and pouring out drink offerings to her?
verses.comment: Idolatrous rites involved family participation, showing how entire households can stray from true worship. True faith requires unity in both practice and belief (cf. Acts 16:31-34).

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, both men and women, who had given him that answer:
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s prophetic vocation is exercised in the face of public opposition, an example of fidelity despite rejection.

verses.text: The Lord did remember and take notice of the incense you burned in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, you and your fathers, your kings and officials, and the people of the land. The Lord could not bear it any longer because of the evil of your deeds and the detestable things you committed.
verses.comment: Every act of worship, whether faithful or not, is seen by God. Persistent sin can reach a point where judgment is inevitable, a theme echoed in the New Testament call to continual repentance (cf. Heb. 10:26-27).

verses.text: So your land became a wasteland, an object of horror and a curse, without inhabitant, as it is today.
verses.comment: Consequences of abandonment of true worship are not merely spiritual but also communal and social.

verses.text: Because you burned incense and sinned against the Lord and did not obey the Lord’s voice or follow His law, His statutes or His testimonies, all this disaster has come upon you, as it is today.
verses.comment: Disaster is traced to deliberate sin and neglect of the divine covenant. Those seeking God must value and keep His commandments (cf. John 14:15).

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people and to all the women, 'Hear the word of the Lord, all you people of Judah who are in the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah addresses the entire community, underscoring the collective responsibility and need for community-wide fidelity.

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, says: You and your wives have spoken with your mouths and fulfilled with your hands, saying, ‘We will surely perform our vows that we have made, to burn incense to the Queen of Heaven and pour drink offerings to her.’ Go ahead then, keep your vows and perform your vows!
verses.comment: There is an ironic tone here; vowing and fulfilling a vow is meant for true worship, not idolatry. The misuse of vows sets up a contrast with the vows and sacraments properly directed toward God.

verses.text: Therefore, hear the word of the Lord, all you of Judah who live in Egypt: Behold, I have sworn by my great name, says the Lord, that My name shall no more be pronounced in the mouth of any man of Judah in all the land of Egypt, saying, ‘As the Lord God lives.’
verses.comment: God’s oath marks a severe judgment. True identity and spiritual inheritance are lost when the name of the Lord is no longer invoked by His people.

verses.text: Behold, I am watching over them for harm and not for good. All the men of Judah in the land of Egypt shall be consumed by the sword and by famine, until there is an end of them.
verses.comment: Where God’s gaze once protected for good, now it ensures discipline. The shift underscores the seriousness of turning away from the truth.

verses.text: And those who escape the sword will return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah, only few in number. Then all the remnant of Judah who came to the land of Egypt to live shall know whose word will stand, Mine or theirs.
verses.comment: A remnant will survive, pointing to God's enduring plan for restoration and unity with His people, even after severe judgment.

verses.text: 'This will be a sign to you,' declares the Lord, 'that I will punish you in this place, so that you may know My words will surely stand against you for harm:'
verses.comment: Signs accompany God's prophetic word. The assurance that God’s word is unbreakable points to the reliability of prophetic promises, foreshadowing Christ as the Word made flesh (John 1:14).

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: 'Behold, I am going to give Pharaoh Hophra king of Egypt into the hands of his enemies, just as I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, his enemy who sought his life.'
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty extends over all nations. The fate of foreign rulers echoes that of Judah’s king, showing there is no security outside of obedient submission to the one true God. This anticipates the universality of the new covenant Jesus would inaugurate.
